Summary Analytical electron microscopy of individual catalyst particles provides much more information than just particle size and shape. The scanning trans- mission electron microscope with analytical facilities allows chemical and structural analysis to be obtained from areas on the order of 10 nm in diam- eter. In this paper, chemical analysis by X-ray emission spectroscopy is de- scribed with examples from studies of supported metal, bismuth molybdate and zeolite catalysts. Qualitative analysis of Pd/Al203 catalysts reveals small concentrations of impurity elements as well as the major components. Phase analysis of bismuth molybdates by quantitative X-ray spectroscopy provides rapid identification of phases present within single catalyst particles. Quanti- tative analysis of zeolite crystals reveals gradients in composition across some types of zeolite crystals. For small ZSM-5 crystals with Si/Al = 10, the parti- cles had either a surface enriched in Si or a nearly homogeneous composition across the particle. For large particles with Si/Al = 40, the particles had more Al near the surface than in the interior. Introduction Characterization of heterogeneous catalysts in the analytical electron microscope (AEM) allows determination of catalyst particle size and shape, crystallographic features and chemical composition on a finer scale than by other methods. While many techniques have been used to study the structure and composition of catalysts including X-ray diffraction, surface analysis, magic-angle NMR, etc., these techniques usually analyze only relatively large areas or volumes of material [1]. The AEM is uniquely suited to the study of the structure and chemistry of individual catalyst particles about 2 nm in diameter and larger. For example, mixtures of phases within a single 0.1 Jum catalyst particle can be examined in detail only by AEM. When AEM is used in conjunction with other techniques, many difficult catalyst characteriza- tion problems can be solved. 0304-5102/83/$3.00 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 358 Analytical electron microscopy carried out in the scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) provides convergent beam electron diffraction (CBED), X-ray emission spectroscopy (XES) and electron energy loss spec- troscopy (EELS) with a lateral spatial resolution of 2 - 20 nm for specimens on the order of 50 nm in thickness. Application of these STEM-based tech- niques to catalyst problems is just beginning; however, several analysis methods already have been developed [2]. The present paper describes appli- cations of X-ray emission spectroscopy to the study of heterogeneous catalysts. Most of the results given here cannot be obtained by any other technique at present. The examples described include Pd crystals supported on A1203, bismuth molybdate phases and ZSM-5 zeolites. Imaging and analysis of supported metal catalysts, such as Pd/Al203, by STEM has begun to receive attention recently [3-5]. One reason for the emphasis on imaging is that a small particle must be imaged clearly before microanalysis can begin. An STEM with a field-emission gun can clearly image particles as small as 2 nm and in many cases provide a diffraction pat- tern or chemical analysis using a stationary electron beam placed directly on a particle. Oxide catalysts containing two heavy metals are ideal specimens for STEM analysis since elemental atomic ratios can be measured relatively easily [6-8]. The case of the bismuth molybdates is of particular interest since three common phases are known: Bi^MoOg, Bi2Mo209and Bi2Mo30i2. A typical multicomponent oxide catalyst used for propene ammoxidation may contain mostly Bi2Mo30i2 when fresh but there are indications that Bi2Mo209 forms during reaction and may actually be the active phase [9, 10]. AEM allows rapid identification of these phases. ZSM-5 is a synthetic high-silica zeolite with extraordinary catalytic properties [11]. Catalytic selectivity is usually related to the size of the regular channels running through the crystal structure. However, catalytic activity and selectivity can be influenced by the number of acid sites that contact reactant molecules. Since the acidity of a region within a zeolite crystal is directly related to the aluminum content in that region [11,12], it is important to know how the average number of Al atoms per zeolite unit cell varies across individual zeolite particles. Several techniques have been used to measure the Al distribution in zeolite crystals including X-ray photo- electron spectroscopy (XPS) [13,14], Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) [15], electron microprobe [16 -18], proton-induced X-ray emission (PIXE) [14] and fast atom bombardment mass spectroscopy (FABMS) [19]. How- ever, AEM is the only technique that can provide actual concentration pro- files across small zeolite crystals of the size actually used in practical cataly- sis. Experimental details Catalyst materials The Pd/7-Al203 catalyst examined here is typical of a wide number of supported metal catalysts. The sample examined was a fresh catalyst used in an industrial hydrogenation process. 359 The bismuth molybdates were synthesized by precipitation from a solution of bismuth nitrate and ammonium molybdate. The resulting amor- phous precipitate was filtered, vacuum dried and calcined at 500 C in air to yield crystalline Bi2Mo30i2. Zeolites Na-A and Na-ZSM-5 were synthesized according to published procedures [20]. Details of the zeolite preparation technique will be pub- lished elsewhere [21]. Bulk chemical analyses of the products were deter- mined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (Al) and gravimetric analysis (Si). For the Na-A zeolite specimens the bulk Si/Al = 0.985. Zeolite ZSM-5 was prepared with two different Si/Al ratios designated ZSM-5(9) and ZSM-5(40) with Si/Al ratios of 9.3 and 39.5, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction pat- terns of these ZSM-5 preparations closely matched those published for ZSM-5 [22]. Magic-angle-spinning "Al NMR spectroscopy [23] did not detected octahedrally coordinated Al, a species which might be expected in the channels, indicating that not more than a few per cent octahedral Al was present. Only tetrahedrally coordinated Al was detected suggesting that the majority of the Al present was associated with the zeolite framework. Specimen preparation for microanalysis In the present work, the as-received particles of catalyst were ground with a mortar and pestle so that many fragments on the order of 0.1 Jum were present. These small particles were dispersed on a carbon support film about 10 - 20 nm thick. The carbon film was supported by a metal grid of a composition that would not interfere with the analysis. The particle dis- persion was made either by spreading the powder out dry and laying a grid carbon-side down on the finest particles or by ultrasonically dispersing the particles in a solvent and allowing a drop of suspension to evaporate on the carbon film. The bismuth molybdate phases and the small particles of zeolite ZSM-5(9) were prepared in this way using distilled water and ethanol, respectively. If spatial relationships must be preserved in particles thicker than 0.1 [Jim, it is useful to embed the particle in epoxy resin and cut thin sections through the particle with a diamond knife microtome. The thin sections are then placed on a microscope grid for examination in the microscope. In general, these thin sections will be less than 0.1 p.m thick. This thin sec- tioning technique was used to prepare the PdlA\^Oy particles and the large Na-A and ZSM-5(40) zeolite crystals. Aficroanafysis Specimens were examined at 100 kV in a Vacuum Generators HB-501 field-emission gun STEM fitted with a Kevex Si(Li) X-ray spectrometer. Figure 1 shows a schematic diagram of the specimen chamber area of the STEM. A focused electron beam scans the specimen in a raster. Electrons that are undeviated by the specimen may be energy-filtered with an electron spectrometer and used to form the bright-field signal. Electrons that are scat- tered or diffracted out of the main beam are collected on an annular dark- 360 SCANNING TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPE SCATTERED AND DIFFRACTED ELECTRONS 1 X-roy EmissionIJLT-JL , Energy - Fig. 1. The electron gun is located near the floor for mechanical stability and the electrons travel upwards. field detector and become the dark-field signal. The interactions of high- energy electrons with specimen atoms will produce inner-shell atomic ionizations and the emission of characteristic X-rays upon de-excitation. These X-rays are collected with the X-ray detector, and the X-ray energy spectrum is displayed on a video screen. The electron beam used for analysis was about 1 - 3 nm in diameter and contained about 10~10 to 10~9 A. The vacuum at the specimen was on the order of 5 X 10~9 Torr. X-Rays were collected over times on the order of 100 s at each area analyzed. The X-ray background was modelled and sub- tracted before X-ray intensity ratios of characteristic peaks were calculated. The Cliff-Lorimer technique [24] was used to convert the X-ray intensity ratios to chemical composition ratios. For the bismuth molybdates, the mea- sured Cliff-Lorimer fe-factor was fe(Bi La/Mo Ka) = 0.398. For zeolites, the fe-factor was fe(Al Ka/Si Ka) = 1.31 as measured from the mineral albite. Relative errors for these fe-values are on the order of 5%. Corrections for absorption and fluorescence were not applied to the results since the speci- men thicknesses examined were kept below the 'thin-film thickness' [25] which was about 0.8 Jixm for bismuth molybdate and about 0.15 p.m for the zeolites. Analyses of particles of thickness equal to the 'thin-film thickness' are liable to an error of 10% if the absorption and fluorescence corrections are neglected. Thus, the analyses given in this paper can be expected to be 361 accurate to about 5 to 15% assuming sufficient X-ray counts are collected [25,26]. For quantitative microanalysis, difficulties can arise from detection of spurious X-rays [27] arising from two sources. High-energy continuum X- rays and stray electrons from the electron column may give rise to signals generated over the entire specimen. This 'hole count' signal was found to be <0.1% of the analytical signal measured from the area of interest. A second source of spurious X-rays may be generated at remote regions of the speci- men by electron scattering and continuum generation at the analysis area itself. Currently, this spurious signal cannot be eliminated but its effects can be minimized by analyzing widely separated particles. Figure 2 is an annular dark-field STEM image of a thin section showing that the Pd penetrates into the alumina to a depth of about 0.5 Jum. The annular dark- field image shows diffraction contrast images from all the Pd particles regard- less of orientation, whereas normal tilted-beam dark-field imaging in the con- ventional transmission electron microscope would reveal diffraction contrast from only a narrow range of crystal orientations. Figure 3 shows an example of qualitative X-ray microanalysis from various areas of a thin section of this catalyst. X-ray spectra from the areas marked in the bright-field image are shown in Figs. 3(b), 3(c) and 3(d) for an 8 nm Pd particle on the AlzOa support, the AlzOa support and the em- bedding epoxy, respectively. This result is expected since calcium is an 363 impurity in even the best aluminas and sulfur can sometimes be picked up in the alumina production process. This example shows that the AEM can detect small impurities present in the support material which under certain circumstances might migrate to the active catalytic material and interfere with the desired reaction. Bismuth molybdates Several preparations of Bi^lM^O^ were examined in the AEM to deter- mine phase purity. About 25 particles from each sample were analyzed. To quantitatively determine the bismuth-to-molybdenum atom ratio for each particle, the Bi La to Mo Ka X-ray intensity ratio was converted to the Bi/Mo atomic ratio using a Cliff-Lorimer fe-factor measured separately. Figure 4(a) shows a histogram of the number of particles detected at various Bi/Mo ratios. For Bi2Mo30i2, sometimes known as the 2/3 compound, the stoichiometric atomic ratio would be Bi/Mo = 0.667. Most of the particles in the experimental distribution were close to Bi2Mo30i2 (peak average Bi/ Mo = 0.656) while a few Mo03 particles (Bi/Mo = 0) were also present. Oxy- gen could not be measured with the X-ray detector used in this work, so each compound was assumed to be fully oxidized [6]. A similar histogram for another preparation of Bi2Mo30i2, shown in Fig. 4(b), indicates the presence of the 1/1 compound, Bi2Mo209, in addition to Bi2Mo30i2. Small amounts of pure Bi (or Bi2C>3) were also detected in these samples which apparently biased the Bi/Mo ratio to a value slightly greater than unity. The reason for the presence of the impurity phases, Mo03 and Bi2Mo2C>9, can be seen from the phase diagram [28] shown in Fig. 5. Bi2Mo30i2 is a line com- pound between two eutectics, so the likelihood of these impurity phases is high. Thus, phase analysis using X-ray elemental ratios can be used to iden- tify phases in multiphase catalysts more rapidly than conventional selected- area electron diffraction, which requires time for film development and pattern analysis. In addition, since phase analysis by AEM is on a particle-by- particle basis, the minimum amount of impurity phase detectable can, in principle, be smaller than that detectable by X-ray diffraction. How- ever, if beam damage is kept below that required for rapid mass transport within the crystal framework, microanalysis profiles across zeolite specimens will reflect true compositional variations across small crystals. To test this microanalysis method, thin sections of zeolite Na-A were examined. This synthetic zeolite is known to have an Si/Al ratio near unity and is believed to have a uniform composition across the crystal [17]. Figure 6(a) shows a con- ventional secondary electron SEM image of the Na-A crystals used in this study. The average particle size is about 2 ^im, so 80 nm thick thin sections were used for microanalysis. Profiles of Si/Al across thin sections of two different crystals are shown in Fig. 7. It is evident that the crystals are homogeneous in composition and have an Si/Al ratio near unity as expected. The average Si/Al ratio for the points shown in Fig. 7 is Si/Al = 0.97 0.05. Conventional chemical analysis gave the bulk Si/Al ratio as 0.985. Thus, the AEM microanalysis method described appears to yield accurate results. A more interesting case occurs for the high-silica zeolite ZSM-5 where the composition across crystals may or may not be constant. The two ZSM-5 preparations examined, ZSM-5(9) and ZSM-5(40), have particle sizes of about 0.3 /im and 2 /xm, respectively (Fig, 6(b) and (c)). Compositional profiles across particles of ZSM-5(9) show two types of particle. Particles which appear to be single crystals show more aluminum in the center of the crystal than near the edges (Fig. 8(a)). Other particles in the same preparation (Fig. 8(b)) exhibited no compositional variations at a spatial resolution of analysis of approximately 30 nm. This second type of particle is composed of many individual crystals about 30 nm in size as shown in Fig. 9. These small crystals stack together with nearly the same orientation into a polycrystalline particle which has no overall chemical gradient. Each small crystal may have a compositional gradient itself but this was difficult to measure since the crystals were not separate. 366 (c) Fig. 6. Surface scanning electron micrographs of zeolites analyzed: (a) zeolite Na-A, (b) ZSM-5(9), (c) ZSM-5(40). Particles of ZSM-5(40) have a very different morphology as shown in Fig. 6(c). A thin section of this type of particle can be assumed to be taken from near the particle center if the outline of a twin (see Fig. 6(c)) can be seen in the thin section. Figure 10 shows the chemical profile of aluminum across such a thin section. In this case more aluminum is present near the surface than in the interior of the particle. At each analysis point the com- position was sampled through the 80 nm section thickness so that an average through-section composition was measured. Conclusions Microanalysis of individual catalyst particles is possible by analytical electron microscopy to a spatial resolution of 10 - 30 nm or better. Thin sectioning of embedded catalyst particles with a diamond-knife microtome offers a general technique for specimen preparation which is especially useful for determining the location of metal particles on the catalyst sup- port and for quantitative microanalysis. The spatial resolution of this tech- nique can reveal small amounts of impurity phases as well as chemical gradients in supposedly uniform catalyst materials. coredata.dc:description: Analytical electron microscopy of individual catalyst particles provides much more information than just particle size and shape. The scanning transmission electron microscope with analytical facilities allows chemical and structural analysis to be obtained from areas on the order of 10 nm in diameter. In this paper, chemical analysis by X-ray emission spectroscopy is described with examples from studies of supported metal, bismuth molybdate and zeolite catalysts. Qualitative analysis of Pd/Al2O3 catalysts reveals small concentrations of impurity elements as well as the major components. Phase analysis of bismuth molybdates by quantitative X-ray spectroscopy provides rapid identification of phases present within single catalyst particles. Quantitative analysis of zeolite crystals reveals gradients in composition across some types of zeolite crystals. For small ZSM-5 crystals with Si/Al = 10, the particles had either a surface enriched in Si or a nearly homogeneous composition across the particle. For large particles with Si/Al = 40, the particles had more Al near the surface than in the interior.
coredata.dc:title: Microanalysis of catalysts by analytical electron microscopy
